summary: This is an email chain from March 2008 discussing the relationship between the state and federal cases against Jeffrey Epstein. It details Epstein's attempts to evade the terms of a proposed non-prosecution agreement, including pleading to a non-registrable offense, avoiding jail time, and litigating restitution. It also mentions his subpoenaing of victims not named in the state indictment, potentially to gather information on the federal investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the state and federal indictments for solicitation and procurement of minors for prostitution. The email details his legal maneuvers to avoid jail time and sex offender registration.

events.title: Scheduled State Trial
events.description: The state case against Epstein currently has a trial date set for July 2008.

events.title: Proposed Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: A federal non-prosecution agreement was proposed requiring Epstein to: 1) plead to a state offense requiring sex offender registration, 2) serve an 18-month incarceration term, and 3) pay restitution to victims. Epstein later tried to evade all three terms.

events.title: Epstein Subpoenas Victims
events.description: Epstein is subpoenaing victims for depositions who are not included in the state indictment, potentially to gain information about the federal investigation.

keyFacts: The state indictment involves two girls, only one of whom is included in the federal indictment. The state charges solicitation of adult prostitution, not a child exploitation offense, despite Florida law not allowing a defense based on ignorance of the victim's age.
Before federal involvement, police were told Epstein would plead to a misdemeanor with no jail time, which prompted the FBI to step in.
Epstein's defense has repeatedly continued the state case, claiming it cannot be resolved until the federal case is resolved.

After signing the non-prosecution agreement, Epstein tried to plead to a non-registrable offense, avoid jail via work release or home confinement, and litigate the restitution terms he had already agreed to.
Due to a defense demand for no contact, the federal prosecutor had not spoken with the State Attorney's Office in over six months, leaving the status of a potential misdemeanor deal unclear.
